reviewText:
Timing challenge game, mobile port.

This game presents you with a set of 50 timing challenges that took me 45 minutes to complete. I can now replay 20 of these to achieve a star for completing them with a single attempt. Presumably, the other 30 levels are either too easy or depend on blind luck, much like a pachinko machine.  (Or maybe there were only 20 levels, and the numbering is weird? Who knows.) There are two or three challenges where you need to think out of the box.

There's no storyline, the game has been designed for touch interfaces to the point where there's no task bar icon, you need to enter your name using the onscreen keyboard, and you drag or click on everything, which doesn't exactly suit levels like the one with the two flippers.

I can see this being a good-looking very short (45 minutes) time-waster on a touch device, but for a desktop game it feels overpriced. If you like the art style, try Little Wheel[www.kongregate.com] instead, for free.

reviewText:
Actually, this is my second attempt to write a review of Collisions. Not that it’s so difficult, but I needed some time to think.

How unfortunate that as humans we are only able to grasp a concept through comparisons, games perhaps being a more extreme example of that limitation. But to compare based on the most superficial aspects is just ridiculous. Those who see Collisions on the Store Page, then immediately think “Limbo” clearly got no further than a quick glance. Those saying “NightSky” are perhaps a bit closer to the mark, but still quite a ways off way off. (Actually, I’ve yet to finish either of those two games. Collisions is much easier, considerably more inexpensive.)

Collisions is a very nice game all on its own. The goal is perhaps the simplest possible, while also a metaphor for all life: move a ball from Point A to Point B, then again and again…. through some 50 levels using the simplest of mouse clicks and drags. If you want the challenge of NightSky (now I’M doing it!) you may be disappointed, because Collisions is essentially a pleasant way to spend an hour or so, whether you’re an 8-year old child, or an old person with time on their hands, such as myself, who doesn’t always want to start the day with a life or death challenge. (But then again….SPOILER.)

None of these Collisions challenges spend more than a moment even in the neighborhood of seeing the shadow of rage-inducing off in the distance, but can nonetheless be satisfying to resolve. If you love pinball as I and most of my friends do, you’ll see that the DEV must as well to base some of the most interesting (IMHO) levels on hitting a ball with a flipper, so s/he must be pretty OK. Some levels aren’t challenges at all, but simply movements on the player’s part to create a mood, or teach an action that may be encountered later. In fact, if I still taught or had grandchildren I would likely use this game for bonding, or perhaps for evaluating a child’s abilities. (Or even an adult’s.) A very good diagnostic tool I should think, mostly because it really is fun. And so much easier to continue to the next level than to contend with the challenge of walking away while still wanting to see what comes next.

One of the more enjoyable aspects of Collisions are the comments (often hints) placed on each level. They display some of the humanity of the DEV, and they are as welcome as they might be out of context in this review.

This is one game that should be played to the very end, as the ending is both amusing and disturbing, and is a great comment on the degree to which we assign meaning to our lives (my ID being a similar comment), and the world we live in….for now. If you can get this game for $2, it’s a must buy.

reviewText:
I liked the idea of it but it just turns out to be a thoroughly average and forgettable experience. The design is quite nice but derivative and the graphics fuzzy. There are 50 levels, some take only a couple of seconds, some take far too long due to the inconsistency and exacting demands of the physics system.

You goal is to move a black ball from entrance to exit via hitting it with pinball paddles, opening and closing sliders, setting up rebounds and most importantly timing everything correctly.

47 of the 50 levels are quite simple while of the other 3, one requires the pixel perfect arrangement of two sliders to set up a ricochet, another requires you to use a demolition ball to hit the ball into the exit and is endlessly frustrating while the third requires you to release another ball to hit the main ball twice but sadly due to the mentioned, we'll call it randomness to be nice, if you release the ball at the same time you might get it on the first try or the 100th and there is really nothing you can do to improve your chances.  I quite liked the arkanoid/pinball level even if the control system couldn't really handle it.


Another in the long list of minimalist hour long puzzle games on steam, some are great, some are terrible and some are just meh. This is meh...

reviewText:
This game is a fun little puzzler. It seems like they put a lot of effort into the engine. Good marks there.

I will not be recommending it for the following ( 4 ) reasons.
1. It took me longer to pay for and install the game than it did to complete. Needs many many many more levels.
2. Oversimplicity.  To me, this is a mini-game that belongs in a bigger title. No real nuance, just physics fun.
3. Any degree of difficulty is out of your control. If a level calls for timing, there are usually other elements that disrupt that timing.  When this happens it feels like you're at a pinball machine with the plunger, but no paddles. Frustrating for the wrong reasons.
4. Please add a point of no return" feature on levels where (if you miss) you have to spend agonizing seconds waiting for your ball to roll into the wrong hole before you can focus on trying again.  On the level that I'm thinking of
date: just move the failure threshold from the point the ball goes off screen
recommended: to the point where the ball hits the "floor". Then when you miss the correct hole
hoursPlayed:
you're already thinking about your next shot.



Fix these things and the game will be worth $10-$20. As is
voteText: it's not quite worth the price. Even though the price is so low. Still

reviewText: Mediocre puzzle game with a nice graphics theme, but unfortunately things blend together too well at times, so you can't always see what the interactive components are. I liked the puzzles that reminded me of the board game, Downfall, with rotating cogs that you drop the ball into, but there were only a couple of those. The puzzles are a mix of skill, timing, and luck... mostly luck. A few of them are fun and well designed, some are okay, and the rest rely too much on luck and involve too much waiting between attempts. Overall, it feels like a good start, but it needs refining before I'd recommend spending time with it.

reviewText: Not a bad little puzzler, the relaxing backgrounds and music were really the best part for me. I've played various physics puzzlers in the past and this one's decent as they go, albeit very short. A handful of levels also rely a little too much on timing against objects that aren't in your control, for instance, trying to motion the ball off a platform to hit a wrecking ball at just the right angle so that it bounces off and reaches the exit gets a little tedious and frustrating. Otherwise though, not a bad one.\n\nSpoilers: Reloading your ammo takes a long time.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Very simple, very short. Probably worth the price (you can eat 2 chease burgers in  less than 30  minutes, right? )

The reason i don't recommend is, is due to the high potential of using these various mechanicals, but they never get the chance to properly interact with each other in a complex way.

In quite too many levels, you either just have to time 1 part right or you are learning about using some new part. Then you get a few extra  levels where that part is used in some manner.

There are a few places, where they combine them and make it interesting. Ex, the wheel with a slider attached, used to convert angular velocity into a kinetic force upon the sphere you guide though. But you can count them on a single hand.

So all in all, while the price isn't something to rant about, it is neither a  game which will satisfy your hunger if you want a platform-physic-puzzle. In most cases the game comes down to timing between 1 or 2 objects, and the ingame help eliminates any possible reason to think, as it hands over the solution right from the start.
voteText: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
A too-simplistic physics puzzle which is short and often relies on chance (someone compared some of the levels to a pachinko machine - which is a fair description)

It looks and sounds nice enough and there's some interesting ideas, but the lack of content and annoyance of 'take your chances' elements killed it for me.

Note: The game has a 'star' system for first-time solutions but that only applies to SOME of the levels - I assume the others are so random it makes no sense to offer that?

It's hard to recommend on that basis - I found it more frustrating than anything else

p.s. I did 12 of the 50 puzzles and I'd not played long enough to leave a review at that point (less than 5 mins) - so there's well under an hour of content here...

reviewText: Ok, so I loved the game's puzzles.  What there were of them.  This is a VERY brief game.  You go through and solve less than ten short puzzles I think and then its over. Seriously.  No exageration.  I was just beggining to get into it when BOOM!-thank you for playing"-credits roll(and you cant escape out of the credits).  What you see for my play time is me having completely finished the game.  30 minutes or so.  So
date: if you dont mind a very short puzzle game then go ahead and buy this one.  The few puzzles that it does has are kind of fun.  If you expect more for your money than a small handful of puzzles then dont buy this game.  Im not going to recomend it based only on its tiny content.  Like I said
recommended: I liked the concept and the few puzzles that it did contain.  PS:  I got this game in one of those 2 dollar's for 10 Steam key deals.  Sadly its one of the better games in the lot that I got.\n\nUPDATE:  Ok
hoursPlayed: so I just went back into the game and looked.  There are actually 50 puzzles!  I saw someone say that in another review and couldnt believe it so I had to check.  So there you have it.  50 puzzles which take less than 30 minutes to solve total.  I guess I was expecting something like Portal II where the challenges would keep coming for quite awhile.  But then you pay more for Portal II."
voteText: October 25, 2015

reviewText: I can't quite put my finger on it, but I did not enjoy this game. I love strategic-timing, puzzle, experimental, and indie games in general but this didn't bring much to the table in my opinion. The entire look of the game was very appealing. Color schemes and contrast were very pleasant. It was the very shortness of the game that I least enjoyed. Half the time I felt like I was being taught a new dynamic aspect to be utilized later on in the game. When, in fact, it was just that level being played out and not much was expanded from that. The difficult levels seemed to be overcome by either very precise timing or pure chance. When your timing was off, it wasn't as though you were frustrated in your lack of precision. It was more a feeling of oh i'll just do this over and over again until the timing happens to coincide". The achievements were a nice goal at first
date: but ultimately impractical unless this is the only game one has available. I don't want to be too harsh because I think this setup has a lot of potential and the overall look to the game is great."

reviewText:
A fun way to kill 30 minutes (longer if you go for the bonuses). Unfortunately, the game crashed on me after I completed it and wiped all my progress. This is unacceptable in a game being sold as a finished product. The developer is active on the forums and has indicated they'll try to reproduce it so I'll update my review accordingly if a fix is released.

UPDATE: The developer has apparently followed through and updated the game with measures to prevent this from happening, along with new achievements. There is now no reason not to pick up a copy of this fun little puzzle game at its current price.

UPDATE: My save data was wiped again, no crash this time. I simply exited the game and when I resumed, all my progress was gone.

UPDATE: The developer found and fixed the issue almost immediately. After force-quitting the game several times, my save data persists. Devs who hang out in the forums and are willing to work with players are simply amazing.

reviewText: The entire challenge of this puzzle game is to hope that you've clicked the correct button at the correct time. It's basically trial and error for many of the challenges where you don't know exactly when to click. Add on top of this the often long reset times for another attempt, and the game quickly feels frustrating and more based on luck, rather than actual puzzle solving.
voteText: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful

reviewText: Man, this game just isn't good. When you look at it, it doesn't look bad at all - it looks like a fun timing-based puzzle game, and the levels compliment the physics quite nicely - but the problem is that the timing is more often trial-and-error than actually getting the right timing, the puzzles are very rarely hard at all, and the biggest problem is that there's a LOT of waiting around; either from waiting for the level elements to fit into place on their own, or from waiting for the ball to come back when you make a mistake. The whole thing just feels like it's made more to look impressive than to be actually fun to play.

reviewText: 7.5/10.\n\nFun little game. Nice music and art style. Some of the puzzles are intuitive and based on reactions, physics and problem solving. Some are unfortunately based on trial and error, or waiting 30 seconds for something to set up, and if you miss you have to wait another 30 seconds. Others are based solely on luck which is annoying. Game is also SUPER short, as being finished in around 45 min. Still worth picking up on sale.
